Modules & Functions

Here are listed some useful functions from the modules accelerator, particles, transport, flux, and injection. They can be used to calculate the properties and CR flux accelerated by the supernova remnant, the transport in the ISM and in the molecular cloud, and the CR interactions within the cloud.

accelerator

This module returns the properties of the supernova remnant, which accelerates particles to high energies.

class craic.accelerator.accelerator(En=<Quantity 1.e+51 erg>)[source]

Calculates the radius and age of supernova remnant in the Sedov-Taylor stage.

SNR_Radius(time)[source]

Classical Sedov-Taylor stage solution for SNR radius (pc) as a function of its age.

Parameters:

time (Quantity) – SNR age. (yr)

SNR_age(size)[source]

Estimates SNR age in the Sedov-Taylor stage (yr) based on its radius.

Parameters:

size (Quantity) – SNR radius. (pc)

escape_time(Ep, typeIIb=True)[source]

Computes the escape time of particles from the supernova remnant (yr).

Parameters:

  • Ep (Quantity) – Energy of particles (GeV)

  • typeIIb (bool) – Type of supernova. Type Ia if False, type IIb if True.

injection

This module computes the proton flux from point or extended sources in the impulsive or continuous injection cases given a set of source properties, based on Aharonian and Atoyan (1996).

craic.injection.compute_fgal(E)[source]

Returns differential proton density of galactic CRs (\(\mathrm{GeV}^{-1}\,\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\)) measured by AMS Collab. (2015), PRL 114 171103.

Parameters:

E (Quantity or array-like) – Energy of Galactic cosmic rays. (GeV)

craic.injection.compute_fgal_dampe(E, E_tran=<Quantity 6.3 TeV>)[source]

Returns differential proton density of galactic CRs (\(\mathrm{GeV}^{-1}\,\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\)) measured by DAMPE Collab (2019), SciAdv aax3793.

Parameters:

  • E (Quantity or array-like) – Energy values of Galactic cosmic rays (GeV).

  • E_tran (Quantity) – Energy at which the low-energy and high-energy Smooth Broken Power-Law (SBPL) fits transition. (TeV)

craic.injection.compute_pflux_continuous_extended(Resc, N_0, Ep, d, a, dens, chi=0.05, ism=1, alpha=2.0)[source]

Compute differential proton flux density (\(\mathrm{GeV}^{-1}\,\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\)) for an continuous injection from the surface of an extended source. The difference to the case of a point source is the normalisation.

Parameters:

  • Resc (astropy.Quantity) – Particle escape radius (=distance from source center). (pc)

  • N_0 (Quantity) – Normalisation of particle distribution function normalising the energy injection rate (L_CR, which could be E_totCR/age). (GeV/s)

  • Ep (Quantity) – Particle energy. (GeV)

  • d (Quantity) – Distance to particle injection location. (pc)

  • a (Quantity) – Time since particle injection at source (can differ from its age). (yr)

  • dens (Quantity) – Density of traversed ambient matter. (\(\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\)) Default value for ISM is 1 \(\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\).

  • chi (float) – Scalar suppression factor for diffusion coefficient, relating to the level of turbulence along the particles path. (ism: 1, clouds: 0.05)

  • alpha (float) – Proton spectrum spectral index. (default: 2.0)

craic.injection.compute_pflux_continuous_point(N_0, Ep, d, a, dens, chi=0.05, ism=1, alpha=2.0)[source]

Compute differential proton flux density (\(\mathrm{GeV}^{-1}\,\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\)) for a continuous injection from a point source as given by Aharonian & Atoyan (1996), A&A 309, 917 (eq. 8).

Parameters:

  • N_0 (Quantity) – Normalisation of particle distribution function normalising the energy injection rate (L_CR, which could be E_totCR/age). (GeV/s)

  • Ep (Quantity) – Particle energy. (GeV)

  • d (Quantity) – Distance to particle injection location. (pc)

  • a (Quantity) – Time since particle injection at source (can differ from its age). (yr)

  • dens (Quantity) – Density of traversed ambient matter. (\(\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\)) Default value for ISM is 1 \(\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\).

  • chi (float) – Scalar suppression factor for diffusion coefficient, relating to the level of turbulence along the particles path. (ism: 1, clouds: 0.05)

  • alpha (float) – Proton spectrum spectral index. (default: 2.0)

craic.injection.compute_pflux_impulsive_extended(Resc, N_0, Ep, d, a, dens, chi=0.05, ism=1, alpha=2.0)[source]

Compute differential proton flux density (\(\mathrm{GeV}^{-1}\,\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\)) for an impulsive injection from the surface of an extended source. The difference to the case of a point source is the normalisation.

Parameters:

  • Resc (Quantity) – Particle escape radius (=distance from source center). (pc)

  • N_0 (Quantity) – Normalisation of particle distribution function normalising the energy injection rate (L_CR, which could be E_totCR/age). (GeV/s)

  • Ep (Quantity) – Particle energy. (GeV)

  • d (Quantity) – Distance to particle injection location. (pc)

  • a (Quantity) – Time since particle injection at source (can differ from its age). (yr)

  • dens (Quantity) – Density of traversed ambient matter. (\(\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\)) Default value for ISM is 1 \(\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\).

  • chi (float) – Scalar suppression factor for diffusion coefficient, relating to the level of turbulence along the particles path. (ism: 1, clouds: 0.05)

  • alpha (float) – Proton spectrum spectral index. (default: 2.0)

craic.injection.compute_pflux_impulsive_point(N_0, Ep, d, a, dens, chi=0.05, ism=1, alpha=2.0)[source]

Compute differential proton flux density (\(\mathrm{GeV}^{-1}\,\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\)) for an impulsive injection from a point source as given by Aharonian & Atoyan (1996), A&A 309, 917 (eq. 3).

Parameters:

  • N_0 (Quantity) – Normalisation of particle distribution function normalising the energy injection rate (L_CR, which could be E_totCR/age). (GeV/s)

  • Ep (Quantity) – Particle energy. (GeV)

  • d (Quantity) – Distance to particle injection location. (pc)

  • a (Quantity) – Time since particle injection at source (can differ from its age). (yr)

  • dens (Quantity) – Density of traversed ambient matter. (\(\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\)) Default value for ISM is 1 \(\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\).

  • chi (float) – Scalar suppression factor for diffusion coefficient, relating to the level of turbulence along the particles path. (ism: 1, clouds: 0.05)

  • alpha (float) – Proton spectrum spectral index. (default: 2.0)

craic.injection.e2R(e, Z=1)[source]

Compute proton rigidity (GV) from particle energy.

Parameters:

  • e (Quantity) – Particle energy. (GeV)

  • Z (float) – Charge number, 1 for a proton.

transport

This modules describes CR transport by calculating magnetic field strength, diffusion coefficient and diffusion radius in the ISM and in a molecular cloud.

class craic.transport.transport(D0=<Quantity 3.e+26 cm2 / s>)[source]

Calculates magnetic field strength, diffusion coefficient and diffusion radius in the ISM and in a molecular cloud.

B_mag(dens)[source]

Returns the magnetic field strength of the cloud (\(\mathrm{\mu G}\)) based on Crutcher et al. 2010, ApJ 725 466 (eq. 21).

Parameter

dens: Quantity

Number density of the molecular cloud (\(\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\))

Diffusion_Coefficient(Ep, dens, chi=0.05, ism=0)[source]

Returns the diffusion coefficient of the ISM or the cloud (\(\mathrm{cm}^{2} \mathrm{/s}\)) based on number density of the medium.

Parameters:

  • Ep (Quantity or array-like) – Energy of particles (GeV)

  • dens (Quantity) – Number density (\(\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\))

R_diffusion(Ep, a, dens, chi=0.05, ism=0)[source]

Returns how far the accelerated particles can propagate by diffusion in the ISM or in the molecular cloud (cm).

Parameters:

  • Ep (Quantity) – Energy of particles (GeV)

  • a (Quantity) – Time of particle propagation in the medium. (seconds)

  • dens (Quantity) – Number density (\(\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\))

particles

This module handles particle interactions by calculating inelastic p-p interaction cross-section, proton cooling time, and the normalisation of proton spectrum.

class craic.particles.particles(alpha=2.0, Ebudget=<Quantity 1.e+50 erg>)[source]

Calculates the p-p cross-section, proton cooling time, and the normalisation for proton spectrum.

NormEbudget(Emin=<Quantity 10. GeV>, Emax=<Quantity 3. PeV>)[source]

Computes the normalisation of the proton flux. Normalises the integral of the energy flux to 1.

Parameters:

  • Emin (Quantity) – Minimum proton energy. (GeV)

  • Emax (Quantity) – Maximum proton energy. (GeV)

sig_ppEK(Ep)[source]

Computes the total inelastic cross section of p-p collisions (\(\mathrm{cm}^{2}\)) as given by Kafexhiu et al. (2014), PhysRevD 90, 123014, (eq. 1).

Parameters:

Ep (Quantity) – Proton energy. (GeV)

t_ppEK(dens, Ep)[source]

Computes the cooling time of protons (s).

Parameters:

  • dens (Quantity) – Number density. (\(\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\))

  • Ep (Quantity) – Proton energy. (GeV)

flux

This module computes the proton flux and kernal functions required to calculate the gamma-ray and neutrino emission from the molecular cloud.”””

class craic.flux.flux[source]

Computes proton flux, gamma-ray and neutrino kernal function from the molecular cloud.

cloud_cell_flux(Rc, Dc, flux)[source]

Compute the total proton influx at the cloud (\(\mathrm{GeV}^{-1}\)).

Parameters:

  • Rc (Quantity) – Radius of the molecular cloud. (pc)

  • Dc (Quantity) – Proton penetration depth in the cloud. (pc)

  • flux (Quantity) – Proton differential flux density at cloud entrance location. (\(\mathrm{GeV}^{-1}\,\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\))

compute_gamma_kernel(Eg, Ep)[source]

Computes the kernel function for the total gamma-ray spectrum from \(\mathrm{\pi^{0}}\) and \(\eta\) meson decay channels according to Kelner et al. 2006, PhysRevD 74, 034018. (numpy.ndarray, indexing [((proton,)gamma)])

Parameters:

  • Eg (Quantity) – Energy of gamma rays. (TeV)

  • Ep (Quantity) – Energy of protons. (GeV)

compute_neutrino_kernel(En, Ep)[source]

Compute the neutrino kernel function for the total neutrino spectrum from \(\pi^{\pm}\) & \(\mu\) decay channels according to Kelner et al. 2006, PhysRevD 74, 034018. Returns kernal functions from \(\mu\) and \(\pi^{\pm}\) with indexing [((proton,)neutrino)].

Parameters:

  • En (Quantity) – Energy of neutrinos. (TeV)

  • Ep (Quantity) – Energy of protons. (GeV)

SNR_Cloud_Flux

This module contains the essential functions to configure the properties of the supernova remnant and the molecular cloud, and compute the gamma-ray and neutrino spectra.

class craic.SNR_Cloud_Flux.SNR_Cloud_Flux(chi=0.05, distance_SNR=<Quantity 2000. pc>, radius_MC=<Quantity 10. pc>, Eg_lo=<Quantity 1. GeV>, Eg_hi=<Quantity 3000. TeV>, accel_type='Impulsive', snr_typeII=True, F_gal=False, palpha=2.0, D_fast=True, flag_low=True)[source]

Class to compute gamma-ray flux from a molecular cloud given the properties of a nearby SNR.

This class calculates gamma-ray and neutrino fluxes from cosmic ray interactions in molecular clouds illuminated by nearby supernova remnants.

__init__(chi=0.05, distance_SNR=<Quantity 2000. pc>, radius_MC=<Quantity 10. pc>, Eg_lo=<Quantity 1. GeV>, Eg_hi=<Quantity 3000. TeV>, accel_type='Impulsive', snr_typeII=True, F_gal=False, palpha=2.0, D_fast=True, flag_low=True)[source]

Initialize the SNR Cloud Flux model by setting the properties of the SNR and the cloud.

Parameters:

  • chi (float) – Scalar suppression factor for diffusion coefficient in clouds, relating to the level of turbulence along the particles path. (ism: 1, clouds: 0.05)

  • distance_SNR (astropy.Quantity) – Distance from earth to the SNR. (~ pc)

  • radius_MC (astropy.Quantity) – Radius of the molecular cloud (~ pc)

  • Eg_lo (astropy.Quantity) – Minimum energy of the produced gamma rays.

  • Eg_hi (astropy.Quantity) – Maximum energy of the produced gamma rays.

  • accel_type (str) – Type of acceleration. Possible values are: Impulsive or Continuous

  • snr_typeII (boolean) – Flag to indicate the SNR scenario considered

  • F_gal (boolean or string) – Flag to include the galactic CR flux contribution. Can switch between two Galactic CR flux inputs “AMS-O2” and “DAMPE”.

  • palpha (float) – Proton spectrum index

  • D_fast (boolean) – Diffusion scenario (fast or slow normalisation)

  • flag_low (boolean) – Flag to include low energy correction

compute_flux(nh2, dist, age) → tuple[source]

Compute the gamma-ray and neutrino flux from a molecular cloud irradiated by a nearby SNR.

Parameters:

  • nh2 (Quantity) – Matter density in the MC. (\(\mathrm{cm}^{-3}\))

  • dist (Quantity) – Distance from SNR center to MC center. (pc)

  • age (Quantity) – SNR age. (yr)

Returns:

(Egs, total_phig, phi_nu, phi_nue_osc, phi_numu_osc, phi_nutau_osc)

EgsQuantity

Gamma-ray (or neutrino, i.e. secondary) energies. (TeV)

total_phigQuantity

Gamma-ray flux. (\(\mathrm{TeV}^{-1}\,\mathrm{cm}^{-2}\,\mathrm{s}^{-1}\))

phi_nuQuantity

Neutrino flux. (\(\mathrm{TeV}^{-1}\,\mathrm{cm}^{-2}\,\mathrm{s}^{-1}\))

phi_nue_oscQuantity

Electron Neutrino flux. (\(\mathrm{TeV}^{-1}\,\mathrm{cm}^{-2}\,\mathrm{s}^{-1}\))

phi_numu_oscQuantity

Muon Neutrino flux. (\(\mathrm{TeV}^{-1}\,\mathrm{cm}^{-2}\,\mathrm{s}^{-1}\))

phi_nutau_oscQuantity

Tau Neutrino flux. (\(\mathrm{TeV}^{-1}\,\mathrm{cm}^{-2}\,\mathrm{s}^{-1}\))

Return type:

tuple
